name: Ceanothus
Relationship: Compare: Berberis; Myrica; Cedron; Agaricus (spleen).Compare: Tinospora cordifolia (a Hindu medicine for chronic cases of fever with enlarged spleen). Polymnia uvedalia - Bears foot - (acute splenitis with tenderness over left hypochondriac region; spleen enlarged, ague cake. Vascular atony, tissues sodden, flabby and non-elastic. Enlarged glands; influences all ductless glands). Ceanothus thrysiflorus - California Lilac - (Pharyngitis, tonsillitis, nasal catarrh, diphtheria. Tincture internally and as a gargle.)

Modalities: Worse: motion; lying on left side
Abdomen: Menses profuse, and yellow weakening leucorrhoea
Splenitis; PAIN ALL UP THE LEFT SIDE
Deep-seated pain in left hypochondrium, hypertrophy of spleen
Unable to lie on left side
Rectum: Diarrhoea; bearing down in abdomen and rectum

details: This remedy seems to possess a specific relation to the spleen. Ague cake of malaria. A left-sided remedy generally. Anaemic patients where liver and spleen are at fault. Chronic bronchitis with profuse secretion. Marked blood pressure, reducing powers. Active hemostatic, materially reducing the clotting of blood.
dosage: First attenuation. Locally as hair tonic.
